title: Vultor ICO (VLT): Enjoy Cash-Less, Bank-Less Transactions
text:
The Vultor ICO introduces a
project with great potential. The company behind it is spearheading a movement towards a secure, fast, and reliable cash-less and bank-less era. In addition, its native token â€“ VLT is very trending currently. The investors are waiting for the ICO sale to start, but the exact date is still unknown. The team plans to start the sale in the near future, though.
Transforming Transactions: Vultor Payâ€™s Digital Revolution
Vultor Pay is not your average payment solution; itâ€™s a transformative force in the digital age. The native cryptocurrency, Vultor (VLT), serves as more than just a digital coin; it fuels network operations and facilitates seamless transactions within the Vultor ecosystem. The aim is clear â€” to turn the world into a secure, fast, and reliable cash-less and bank-less environment.
Seamless and Secure: VultorR redefines Digital Payments
At its core, Vultor is a cutting-edge payment solution that revolutionizes the way we transact. Leveraging NFC technology, it also offers a seamless and secure method of making contactless payments. Furthermore, the platform bypasses traditional payment intermediaries like Visa and Mastercard. The focus is on empowering users to take control of their financial interactions with fast and convenient transactions directly from their mobile devices.
Blockchain Transparency: Empowering Users with Trust
What sets Vultor apart is its unwavering commitment to transparency and user autonomy. Through the power of blockchain technology, it ensures transparency in transactions. Besides, the company provides a level of trust and accountability often absent in traditional payment systems. Users have full control over their funds and can easily monitor their transactions. All of these make Vultor a reliable and secure payment solution.
Comprehensive Ecosystem: Enabling Merchants and Users Alike
Beyond contactless payments, Vultor also offers a comprehensive ecosystem for merchants to integrate its payment solutions seamlessly. This integration enhances user experience, and also opens up new possibilities for merchants. It allows them to tap into the benefits of cryptocurrency transactions while enjoying the simplicity and efficiency of Vultorâ€™s user-friendly interface.
VLT Token: The Heart of the Vultor Ecosystem
At the heart of the ecosystem lies the VLT token, a utility token that serves as the key to accessing Vultorâ€™s services. Users can utilize VLT to make transactions, enjoy discounts, and participate in the growing Vultor community. As the network expands with more merchants and users embracing the Vultor payment solution, the value of the VLT token is set to soar.
Reshaping the Future: Vultorâ€™s Vision
Vultorâ€™s vision goes beyond transactions; it aims to liberate individuals and businesses from the constraints of traditional banking systems. With its innovative technology, user-centric approach, and commitment to transparency, Vultor is on the verge of reshaping the future of payments. It promises a seamless digital transaction experience that empowers everyone in the digital landscape.
A New Era Unveiled with Vultor ICO
Moreover, the upcoming Vultor ICO signifies more than just the introduction of a
digital token; it heralds the dawn of a new era in digital transactions. Besides, the company aims to revolutionize the way we perceive and conduct cashless and bankless transactions. Thus, Vultor is poised to leave an indelible mark on the world of payments.

author: Nigell Moses / WWL Louisiana
title: 'King Cake Drive-Thru' debuts in New Orleans | wwltv.com
text: METAIRIE, La. â€” New Orleans will have its first-ever king cake drive-thru starting on Saturday. A new bakery is offering locals their favorites with just a stop at the window. King Cake Drive-Thru will be a new bakery in Metairie. Owners said they hope the new drive-thru will offer locals the quick convenience of buying king cakes for Carnival season. "Keep your kids in the car. Donâ€™t worry about parking. Pull up and head out," said owner Mike Graves. "You can grab a favorite or snag a new king cake on the way to the office or on the way home for the family." Expect king cakes from popular bakeries across Greater New Orleans including Brennanâ€™s, Gambinoâ€™s, and Bittersweet Confections. Along with other favorites like Vietnamese Doughnguyenerâ€™s King Cakes, Clesiâ€™s Crawfish King Cakes, Empanolaâ€™s Guava Cream Cheese King Cakes, and Kimi Bakes King Cake Cream Puffs. Other convenience items will be offered such as a party pack complete with plates, napkins, utensils and a king cake knife for on-the-go use. The bakery will also have a weekly rotating menu. "If New Orleans can do drive-thru daiquiris, it surely can do a King Cake Drive-Thru," said Graves. King Cake Drive-Thru will have its grand opening on Saturday, Jan. 6 at 7 a.m. The bakery is located at 1009 Metairie Road in Metairie. Hours of operation will be Friday-Sunday from 7 a.m. until 7 p.m. ( or until sold out) throughout Mardi Gras season. â–º Get breaking news from your neighborhood delivered directly to you by downloading the new FREE WWL-TV News app now in the [IOS App Store](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/new-orleans-news-from-wwl/id1453203460) or [Google Play](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.doapps.android.mln.MLN_d6bcd10196773d6203b7e9b10e53fea3&hl=en_US).

author: Jazmine Angulo
title: 314 sismos en menos de cinco meses: el IGP monitorea un paÃ­s que vibra y una Lima en riesgo silencioso - Infobae
text:
CientÃ­ficos chilenos esperan terremoto en el norte de ese paÃ­s. A simple vista, muchas ciudades del paÃ­s parecen mantenerse en calma. Las rutinas se desarrollan sin alteraciones, los edificios siguen en pie y las calles no muestran daÃ±os. Sin embargo, bajo tierra , el movimiento nunca se detiene. PerÃº estÃ¡ sobre una zona de colisiÃ³n de placas tectÃ³nicas y, aunque la mayorÃ­a de sus habitantes no lo percibe, el territorio vibra constantemente.
Durante los primeros cuatro meses de este aÃ±o , el Instituto GeofÃ­sico del PerÃº (IGP) detectÃ³ 314 sismos en distintas regiones. Aunque casi todos fueron leves, algunos se sintieron con claridad en zonas urbanas. El mÃ¡s reciente ocurriÃ³ el 7 de mayo a las 9:44 de la maÃ±ana y alcanzÃ³ una magnitud de 3.8, con epicentro a 14 kilÃ³metros al oeste del Callao. No provocÃ³ daÃ±os, pero es parte de una secuencia que evidencia la permanente actividad en el subsuelo peruano.
Esta vigilancia continua es responsabilidad del Centro SismolÃ³gico Nacional (Censis), una unidad del IGP equipada con tecnologÃ­a de Ãºltima generaciÃ³n. SegÃºn el jefe del IGP, Hernando Tavera , la frecuencia de los movimientos sÃ­smicos es un indicador directo de la dinÃ¡mica geolÃ³gica del paÃ­s. â€œEl suelo peruano estÃ¡ en constante movimiento y eso puede interpretarse como un signo vitalâ€, explicÃ³. El Censis, aÃ±adiÃ³, â€œgenera informaciÃ³n permanente y en tiempo realâ€.
314 sismos en lo que va del aÃ±o
Un sismo de magnitud 4 se registrÃ³ en Lima la noche del sÃ¡bado SegÃºn los datos recogidos por el IGP hasta el 7 de mayo, en el aÃ±o se registraron 314 sismos . El Centro SismolÃ³gico Nacional detallÃ³ que en enero se reportaron 76 eventos, en febrero 79, en marzo 81, en abril 61 y en los primeros siete dÃ­as de mayo 17. Las magnitudes variaron entre 3,5 y 5,4.
Para lograr este nivel de monitoreo, el Censis cuenta con una red de 75 estaciones sÃ­smicas distribuidas en todo el paÃ­s, cuyos sensores envÃ­an datos vÃ­a satÃ©lite a la sede principal y a un centro alterno en Huancayo. Este despliegue permite emitir alertas de forma casi inmediata a las entidades que gestionan el riesgo de desastres, como el Instituto Nacional de Defensa Civil (Indeci) o la DirecciÃ³n de HidrografÃ­a de la Marina de Guerra del PerÃº, en caso de riesgo de tsunami. â€œEl equipo del Censis estÃ¡ formado por profesionales altamente capacitadosâ€, asegurÃ³ Tavera. â€œEllos analizan y procesan los datos de la Red SÃ­smica Nacional antes de emitir los reportes tÃ©cnicosâ€, precisÃ³.
El silencio de Lima y la amenaza latente
Los distritos mÃ¡s seguros y vulnerables durante un terremoro en Lima. (Foto: Infobae PerÃº/Agencia Andina) Mientras en muchas regiones del paÃ­s la tierra vibra con regularidad, Lima carga con un fenÃ³meno distinto: el silencio. Desde 1746 no se ha registrado un terremoto de gran magnitud en la capital, lo que, en tÃ©rminos geolÃ³gicos, significa una acumulaciÃ³n prolongada de energÃ­a sÃ­smica.
â€œEl Ãºltimo gran sismo en la costa central ocurriÃ³ en 1746. Tuvo una magnitud entre 8.8 y 9â€, recordÃ³ Tavera. â€œDesde entonces no hubo otro de esa intensidad, por lo que se ha acumulado energÃ­a durante 279 aÃ±osâ€. El jefe del IGP explicÃ³ que esta zona se encuentra frente a la interfaz de las placas de Nazca y Sudamericana, donde el choque tectÃ³nico genera una gran tensiÃ³n. â€œEsa frecuencia de sismos nos ha permitido investigar y llegar a la conclusiÃ³n de que existe la probabilidad de que, frente a la costa de Lima , pueda ocurrir en algÃºn momento un sismo de magnitud elevada; por eso en los simulacros ensayamos sismos de magnitud 8.8â€, seÃ±alÃ³.
Para el experto, basta observar cÃ³mo estÃ¡n construidas muchas viviendas en la capital para entender el riesgo. â€œCuando ocurre un sismo, el suelo se sacude por distintos lados o niveles de intensidad y, si las viviendas no son capaces de soportar, pueden colapsarâ€, advirtiÃ³.
PrevenciÃ³n y preparaciÃ³n
temblor - sismo - IGP - mochila de emergencia Frente a este panorama, el IGP y Defensa Civil insisten en la importancia de la preparaciÃ³n ciudadana. La principal recomendaciÃ³n es ubicar con anticipaciÃ³n las zonas seguras dentro de cada inmueble . Estas deben estar libres de obstÃ¡culos, ser accesibles e iluminadas. Ante un sismo, se sugiere agacharse, cubrirse y sujetarse, protegiendo especialmente la cabeza y el cuello.
â€œSi no podemos agacharnos, bajemos lo mÃ¡s que podamos y mantengÃ¡monos lejos de ventanas u objetos que nos puedan caer encimaâ€, seÃ±ala el protocolo. Las autoridades tambiÃ©n recomiendan mantener listas las mochilas de emergencia, adaptadas a las necesidades de cada familia. Los reportes del Censis se emiten apenas se detecta un evento sÃ­smico . La rapidez con la que se entrega esta informaciÃ³n permite activar protocolos de respuesta y alertar a la poblaciÃ³n. â€œLa informaciÃ³n que genera el Censis es permanente y en tiempo realâ€, reiterÃ³ Tavera.
Aunque no todos los sismos provocan daÃ±os, cada uno recuerda la condiciÃ³n sÃ­smica del paÃ­s. Las cifras, que ya suman 314 movimientos en menos de cinco meses , muestran que el riesgo es constante. Para los especialistas, la clave estÃ¡ en estar preparados antes de que la tierra vuelva a sacudirse con fuerza.

author: Leonel Araiza Estrada
title: Abril de 2024 fue el quinto mes mÃ¡s caluroso en Guanajuato desde 1985 - PeriÃ³dico AM
text: [Guanajuato](https://www.am.com.mx/guanajuato)el Abril de 2024 fue el quinto mes mÃ¡s caluroso en Guanajuato desde 1985 Debido a esto, la sequÃ­a excepcional se registrÃ³ en 11 municipios de Guanajuato que podrÃ­an ocasionar pÃ©rdidas de cultivos y escasez de agua Guanajuato.- Abril de 2024 se convirtiÃ³ en el quinto mes mÃ¡s caluroso para Guanajuato desde 1985 (cuando comenzÃ³ el monitoreo atmosfÃ©rico); de esta forma la sequÃ­a excepcional se registrÃ³ en 11 municipios de Guanajuato que podrÃ­an ocasionar pÃ©rdidas de cultivos y escasez de agua. De acuerdo con el monitor de SequÃ­a de la ComisiÃ³n Nacional del Agua (Conagua), el 79 % de los municipios de MÃ©xico se encuentran en alguna condiciÃ³n de sequÃ­a. En el caso de Guanajuato, la totalidad del estado se mantiene en alguna categorÃ­a de sequÃ­a. Al corte del 30 de abril del 2024, la Conagua reportÃ³ que en Guanajuato eran 19 municipios en sequÃ­a severa, 16 en sequÃ­a extrema y 11 en sequÃ­a excepcional. Para el organismo federal, la sequÃ­a excepcional se caracteriza por pÃ©rdidas generalizadas de cultivos o pastos, riesgo de incendios, escasez total de agua en embalses, arroyos y pozos. Con probabilidad de una situaciÃ³n de emergencia por la ausencia de agua. Actualmente los municipios que se encuentran en esta categorÃ­a son: San Miguel de Allende, Atarjea, Doctor Mora, Dolores Hidalgo CIN, San Diego de la UniÃ³n, San JosÃ© Iturbide, San Luis de la Paz, Santa Catarina, Tierra Blanca y XichÃº. El 31 de diciembre del 2023 ninguno de los municipios guanajuatenses se encontraba en sequÃ­a excepcional, y lentamente varios abandonaron la sequÃ­a extrema y pasaron a excepcional. Mientras que en sequÃ­a extrema, caracterizada por riesgos de incendios y algunas pÃ©rdidas generalizadas de cultivos ademÃ¡s de restricciones en el consumo de agua, estÃ¡n: Apaseo el Alto, Apaseo el Grande, Celaya, Manuel Doblado, Comonfort, Guanajuato, Irapuato, JerÃ©cuaro, LeÃ³n, Ocampo, PÃ©njamo, Romita, Salamanca, San Felipe, y Santa Cruz de Juventino Rosas y Silao. Y en sequÃ­a severa se encuentra el resto: Abasolo, AcÃ¡mbaro, Coroneo, Cortazar, CuerÃ¡maro, HuanÃ­maro, Jaral del Progreso, MoroleÃ³n, Pueblo Nuevo, PurÃ­sima del RincÃ³n, Salvatierra, San Francisco del RincÃ³n, Santiago MaravatÃ­o, Tarandacuaro, Tarimoro, Uriangato, Valle de Santiago, VillagrÃ¡n y Yuriria. Abril 2024 uno de los mÃ¡s calurosos De acuerdo con la ComisiÃ³n Nacional del Agua, abril del 2024 fue el sexto abril mÃ¡s caluroso en Guanajuato desde que iniciÃ³ de las variables climÃ¡ticas en 1985, con una temperatura mÃ¡xima promedio de 31.6 grados centÃ­grados. Los abriles mÃ¡s calurosos, temperaturas mÃ¡ximas promedio, tambiÃ©n se registraron en 2008 (35.5 grados), 1987 (33.8 grados), 2006 (32.7 grados), 2012 (32.6 grados), 2020 (32.3 grados), 2024 (31.6 grados). Pronostican lluvias para Guanajuato Marcos Irineo Esquivel Longoria, del Centro de Ciencias AtmosfÃ©ricas y Observatorio MeteorolÃ³gico de la Universidad de Guanajuato, informÃ³ que entre este jueves 09 de mayo y el sÃ¡bado 11 de mayo de 2024 es probable que aumente el potencial de lluvia en algunos puntos especÃ­ficos de Guanajuato. â€œNo solo en la zona norte sino tambiÃ©n en algunas partes del centro y extremo suresteâ€, indicÃ³. Se precisÃ³ que existe una probabilidad de entre 30 % y 50 % para que comience a llover en San Luis de la Paz y otras zonas del noroeste del estado, entre viernes y sÃ¡bados las lluvias podrÃ­an ser en Dolores Hidalgo, San Luis de la Paz, Ocampo, San Felipe, San Miguel de Allende, Guanajuato Capital y Celaya. Aunque el calor extremo tambiÃ©n continuarÃ¡, asÃ­ como la onda de calor prolongada. DAR [Guanajuato](https://www.am.com.mx/guanajuato)el AManece Guanajuato Mantente al dÃ­a con las Ãºltimas noticias de Guanajuato, suscrÃ­bete gratis con tu correo

author: Canadian Press
title: Today-History-Dec29
text:
Today in History for Dec. 29:
In 1170, the Archbishop of Canterbury, Thomas Becket, was murdered on the altar of Canterbury Cathedral by knights of King Henry II.
In 1813, the British burned Buffalo, N.Y., during the War of 1812.
In 1837, the American ship "Caroline," which had been supplying William Lyon Mackenzie's rebels, was set on fire by the British and sent over Niagara Falls. At least one American was killed and a difficult diplomatic impasse between Britain and the United States followed.
In 1845, Texas became a U.S. state.
In 1851, the first American Young Men's Christian Association was organized, in Boston.
In 1877, employees of Canada's Grand Trunk Railroad went on strike, in support of members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers who had been fired. The strike was broken by the use of militia and non-union workers.
In 1890, the last battle in the American-Indian wars took place at Wounded Knee Creek, S.D. About 350 half-starved Sioux gathered on the Pine Ridge Reservation for a Ghost Dance, a religious ceremony in which the Indians believed their dead would rise again and lead them to good hunting grounds. When the Sioux refused to hand over their weapons to the 7th Cavalry, the troops opened fire. About 150 Indians, half of them women and children, and 25 soldiers, died in the battle.
In 1908, the first gold coin and sovereigns were minted in Canada.
In 1916, Grigory Rasputin, the so-called "Mad Monk" who'd wielded great influence with Czar Nicholas II, was murdered by a group of Russian noblemen in St. Petersburg.
In 1919, Sir William Osler, who's been called the most influential physician in history, died in Oxford, England at age 70. Known as "the father of clinical medicine," the Ontario native was a pioneer in emphasizing a patient's state of mind in achieving a cure. His 1892 medical text, "The Principles and Practice of Medicine," was considered authoritative for over three decades.
In 1921, William Lyon Mackenzie King succeeded Arthur Meighen as prime minister of Canada. King led the Liberal party for 25 years and was prime minister for more than 21 years. He resigned from office in 1948 at age 74. He died on July 22, 1950.
In 1934, Japan formally denounced the Washington Naval Treaty of 1922.
In 1940, German aircraft dropped thousands of incendiary bombs on central London during the Second World War, causing the worst fire damage in the British capital since the Great Fire of 1666. St. Paul's Cathedral survived, but eight other ancient churches were badly damaged.
In 1944, Canadian pilot Dick Audet shot down five enemy planes in 10 seconds during the Second World War.
In 1952, a six-kilogram kidney stone was removed from an 80-year old woman by a doctor in London, England. At the time, it was the largest recorded in medical history.
In 1967, Parliament abolished the death penalty, except for the killing of prison guards or police officers, for a five-year trial period. The legislation was renewed in 1973, before hanging was totally abolished in 1976. Canada's last executions were in 1962.
In 1969, European industries and services were paralyzed by a major influenza epidemic.
In 1970, Roy Ivor, 91, internationally known naturalist, lost his bird sanctuary at Mississauga, Ont., in a fire.
In 1972, an Eastern Airlines TriStar jet crashed on approach to Miami International Airport, killing 101 people.
In 1975, 11 people were killed and 74 injured when a bomb exploded in a baggage claim area at the La Guardia airport in New York.
In 1981, U.S. President Ronald Reagan imposed trade sanctions on the Soviet Union to protest the imposition of martial law in Poland following the rise of Solidarity, the independent trade union movement.
In 1989, Canada became the first country to ban smoking on domestic flights.
In 1989, writer Vaclav Havel was elected as president of the Czech Republic as politicians voted to end the Communist party's 40-year monopoly of power.
In 1991, Susan Wright, one of Canada's best-known stage actresses, died in Stratford, Ont., at age 44.
In 1992, Fernando Collor de Mello resigned as president of Brazil minutes before the opening of his impeachment trial.
In 1996, distinguished Canadian poet Dorothy Livesay died at age 87.
In 1998, four tourists, including one Canadian, were killed by their kidnappers after Yemeni troops stormed a remote mountain hideaway where they were being held by Islamic extremists.
In 2008, Israel called an "all-out war" against Hamas as its air attacks killed more than 300 people in Gaza in three days, the bloodiest fighting between Israelis and Palestinians since the 1967 war.
In 2008, former prime minister Sheikh Hasina won a landslide victory in Bangladeshâ€™s first election in seven years.
In 2008, Canada's junior hockey team won The Canadian Press team of the year for its gold medal win at the World Jr. Championship.
In 2009, Const. Eric Czapnik, 51, was stabbed to death outside an Ottawa Hospital, becoming the first Ottawa police officer to die in the line of duty since 1983. A Mountie under suspension was arrested in the attack. (In 2012, Kevin Gregson was found guilty of first-degree murder.)
In 2009, China executed a British man (Akmal Shaikh) convicted of drug smuggling in its first execution of a European citizen in half a century.
In 2010, police in Denmark and Sweden halted an imminent terrorist attack by arresting five men who planned to shoot as many people as possible at the Jyllands-Posten newspaper's Copenhagen newsdesk, which published cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad in 2005.
In 2011, Jennifer Heil, Canada's most successful female freestyle skier, was named The Canadian Press female athlete of the year. She ended her career earlier in the year with an unexpected sweep of the moguls and dual moguls gold medals at the world championships.
In 2011, fed-up voters in Jamaica threw out the ruling party and delivered a landslide triumph to the opposition People's National Party and its leader, former Prime Minister Portia Simpson Miller.
In 2013, Michael Schumacher, the most successful driver in Formula One history, suffered a serious head injury while skiing in the French Alpine resort of Meribel. The German driver was placed in a medically induced coma. In June 2014, he left a French hospital no longer in a coma and transferred to neighbouring Switzerland to continue his recovery.
In 2017, Canada lost 4-3 in a shootout to the United States in international hockey's first outdoor game in Orchard Park, N.Y.
In 2018, the first North Atlantic right whale calf of the winter season was spotted off the Florida coast heading north with its mother, a known resident of the Gulf of St. Lawrence. The Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission said on Facebook that the two endangered whales were sighted near the mouth of the state's St. Johns River.
In 2020, Independent Sen. Elaine McCoy, who was appointed to the chamber in 2005 after a career in Alberta politics, died at the age of 74. Alberta Premier Jason Kenney paid tribute to McCoy, calling her a persuasive and unapologetic advocate for the province's workers and energy sector.
In 2021, Rideau Hall released the names of the 135 newest additions to the Order of Canada. Among the list of recipients was former senator Murray Sinclair, the noted Indigenous advocate who chaired the Truth and Reconciliation Commission into residential schools. Also on the list was author Yann Martel, known for his book ``Life of Pi'' released two decades ago.
In 2021, Damian Warner beat out sprinter Andre De Grasse and soccer star Alphonso Davies to win the Lionel Conacher award as The Canadian Press male athlete of the year. The 32-year-old from London, Ont., won decathlon gold in dominating fashion at the Tokyo Olympics.
In 2021, British socialite Ghislaine Maxwell was convicted of helping American financier Jeffrey Epstein sexually abuse teenage girls. The verdict capped a month-long trial featuring sordid accounts of the sexual exploitation of girls as young as 14, told by four women who described being abused as teens.
In 2021, a Canadian woman was among seven people in custody in Hong Kong after police raided an online pro-democracy news organization. Two male editors who worked at Stand News were charged with conspiracy to publish a seditious publication, a day after the outlet said it would cease operations following the Wednesday morning raid. Five others being detained for questioning included Hong Kong-born-Canadian pop singer and board member Denise Ho.
In 2021, Canada's border agency temporarily closed two ports of entry in the Atlantic region due to COVID-19. The CBSA said the affected offices were in Bathurst, New Brunswick and Charlottetown, P.E.I. Spokeswoman Judith Gadbois-St-Cyr said service at the small offices was being suspended because of COVID infections and close contacts among staff.

The Canadian Press
